title: How do I get out of a corporation that I'm a minority shareholder in (25%) when the other members won't cooperate?
question: The S Corporation owes about $500,000 to various vendors, including the FTB and some fees and penalties to the EDD. The other 2 members who hold 75%, wish to keep the corporation alive (without paying any debt, they have a pie in the sky idea of taking the company through an SEC audit to take it on the pink sheets or OTCBB). I wish to dissolve it (which would probably require a corporate bk).
question_tags: Incorporation,S-corporation,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Employee wages and payroll taxes,Starting a business
answers:
Attorneys Doland and Smith provided good big-picture answers, particularly as concerns your need to obtain legal representation.

Addressing your immediate desire to distance yourself from the corporation:
- You can resign as an officer and a director by providing written notice to the board of directors.
- You cannot unilaterally relinquish your shares. However, you can transfer your shares to the corporation, or to one or both of the other shareholders, if the recipient(s) agree(s) to accept the shares.

You defintely need to seek legal representation because you plan to file bankruptcy which is not something you should embark upon without representation. There appear to be tax obligations (EDD) that you may need to discuss with a tax attorney because you may be liable for unpaid payroll taxes which you may not be able to discharge in BK. You also my need to discuss your matter with a business attorney in order to insure that you have been apprised of all you legal options in properly resigning from the Corp. and limiting your personal liabilty for the corp's debts..

You need to clearly understand that what you are seeking to do is a step by step process that has potential land mines along the way. Get some sound legal advice before you cause yourself an unanticipated legal problem that could be avoided.

You are really getting way ahead of yourself by the time you talk about filing bankruptcy for a new start. You need to get copies of all the documents and sit down with a lawyer. Some debts belong only to the corporation, not the shareholders, even if income is "passed through" by virtue of being having made a subchapter S election. Some are problematic, like EDD obligations. Gosh only knows if your shares were ever issued properly, if you have a management agreement, etc. Don't be offended, but when you talk about an SEC "audit" it is obvious you have all never used a lawyer which was a big mistake. Hire an attorney to work out a strategy with you. Your co-shareholders will take you much more seriously if they get a letter from an attonrey instead of you personally. We do this type of work if you wish to contact me through the Avvo profile. There are other very good Avvo attorneys in LA that do the same.
